topic.title: HP Helion 2.0 Development Platform: Upgrading from HP Helion Development Platform 1.1

titlealts.searchtitle: How to Preserve the Helion Development Platform when Upgrading from Helion OpenStack 1.1 to 1.1.1

topic.shortdesc: The process for upgrading Helion OpenStack without affecting the Helion Development Platform. You do not need to un/reinstall.

li.p: If the Helion Development Platform was not previously installed, simply upgrade Helion OpenStack from version 1.1 to 1.1.1 and then install Helion Development Platform 1.3.

If the Helion Development Platform was previously installed:
Stop the Helion Development Platform services and the control plane virtual machines.
Perform the Helion OpenStack update. This will update the Marketplace, Messaging, and Database services.
Install the new version of the Application Lifecycle Service.
Restart the Helion Development Platform services and the control plane VMs.

section.title: Stopping the Services and VMs
section.p: Before stopping services, check that the service control plane is in healthy state (this is required for trove and marketplace).
To run the Helion Development Platform scripts, perform the following steps:

ol.li: Set dev_plat_service to the name of the service (trove/marketplace).
Set skip_ha_checks if the service control plane is not running in HA mode.
Provide path to the SSH private key that can be used to connect to the service control plane VMs.
Back up the ansible folder and move the latest build to its location:mv /opt/stack/tripleo-ansible /opt/stack/tripleo-ansible-old mv /opt/stack/tripleo-ansible-build-81 /opt/stack/tripleo-ansible

Source credentials for the Nova account which was used to set up the Helion Developer Platform service by entering:cd /opt/stack/tripleo-ansible source overcloud.stackrc source /opt/stack/venvs/openstack/bin/activate ansible-playbook \ --extra-vars dev_plat_service=<service> \ --private-key <path to SSH private key> \ --skip_ha_checks=True \ -u heat-admin \ -i plugins/inventory/dev_platform_heat.py \ playbooks/dev-platform/dev_platform_pre_check.yml

If the service is in a healthy state, stop it using the following commands. (If the service is not in a healthy state, contact customer support.)ansible-playbook \ --extra-vars dev_plat_service=<service> \ --private-key <path to SSH private key> \ -u heat-admin \ -i plugins/inventory/dev_platform_heat.py \ playbooks/dev-platform/dev_platform_stop.yml

section.p: You can now run the update script.

section.title: Restarting the Services and VMs
section.p: After running update on the overcloud, the VMs running on the Compute hosts are in a shutdown state, so you need to first start the Helion Development Platform service control plane VMs. To do this:

ol.li: Source the credentials for the Nova account which was used to set up the Helion Developer Platform service by entering:cd /opt/stack/tripleo-ansible scripts/dev-platform/restart_dev_platform_instances.bash

Since you have already sourced correct overcloud Nova credentials, you can simply verify the status of Helion Developer Platform service VMs by running the nova list command and checking the status field.

To start the Helion Development Platform service, enter:ansible-playbook \ --extra-vars dev_plat_service=<service> \ --private-key <path to SSH private key> \ -u heat-admin \ -i plugins/inventory/dev_platform_heat.py \ playbooks/dev-platform/dev_platform_start.yml
